title: Agricultural product quality schemes: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on agricultural product quality schemes
background: The European Commission proposed a regulation (COM(2010)0733) to reform EU agricultural product quality schemes, including protected designations of origin and geographical indications, aiming to simplify procedures and enhance market competitiveness. The Parliament will discuss measures to streamline quality certification systems and introduce new quality terms for agricultural products.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the introduction of the "mountain product" designation, aligning with their commitment to rewarding quality-driven agriculture and recognizing the unique challenges faced by producers in high-altitude regions.  
EPP applauds the streamlined certification processes and mandatory EU logo use for geographical indications, which enhance consumer trust and market visibility while reducing bureaucratic burdens for small-scale producers.  
EPP welcomes strengthened protections for EU quality schemes in international trade agreements, underscoring their priority to defend European agricultural excellence against global imitation.  
EPP proposes revisiting supply management mechanisms for producer consortias during CAP reform discussions to ensure fair market equilibrium, framing this as an enhancement opportunity rather than opposition to the current issue.  
EPP endorses the integration of traditional specialty guarantees and local sales labels, viewing these as critical tools for preserving culinary heritage and empowering regional economies.

GREEN_EFA rejects the diluted enforcement mechanisms in Article 12, absolutely opposeing with their demand for strict penalties against counterfeit agricultural products.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the exclusion of Amendment 103 on geographical indications, which fails to protect small-scale producers as outlined in their rural development agenda.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Council’s disregard for colegislator parity, creating market distortions inconsistent with their fair competition principles.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to mandate CAP funding allocations for certification systems, undermining sustainability commitments.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the compromise text abandons original transparency goals, particularly in labeling standards critical to consumer trust.

SD strongly approves the enhanced geographical indication protections in Articles 4-6, particularly the ex officio enforcement against product imitation, aligning with S&D's commitment to fair producer compensation.  
SD applauds the inclusion of "mountain farming" quality terms as a critical step toward recognizing regional production diversity, while proposing extending equivalent recognition to island agricultural products through amended Annex II specifications.  
SD endorses the simplified PDO/PGI authorization procedures as effectively advancing small-scale producers' market access, a longstanding S&D rural development priority.  
SD emphasizes the need to address unresolved production planning mechanisms for protected designations during upcoming CAP reforms, ensuring alignment with supply management tools in the milk sector.  
SD approves the mandatory sustainability criteria in Article 12 as foundational to reconciling quality schemes with environmental priorities, urging accelerated implementation timelines.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue as it absolutely rejects with their opposition to market liberalization policies that perpetuate rural instability and undermine quality scheme effectiveness.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal for neglecting systemic income inequality and purchasing power erosion, which are core barriers to equitable agricultural development.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the issue’s failure to challenge deregulated global trade frameworks that weaken geographical indications and expose small producers to unfair competition.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s omission of structural reforms to counter neoliberal policies crushing rural economies, rendering sustainability goals unattainable.  
GUE_NGL asserts that without reversing agricultural deregulation, consumer protections and traditional product guarantees remain hollow, opposing its adoption.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0733) concerning agricultural product quality schemes, adopting amendments to enhance transparency, consumer protection, and fair competition for farmers and producers. It emphasized the need for clear labeling standards, geographical indications, and traditional specialty guarantees to safeguard product authenticity and prevent market distortions. The resolution stressed aligning quality schemes with sustainability goals, promoting environmentally friendly practices, and ensuring small-scale producers’ access to certification systems. It called for robust enforcement mechanisms, including stricter penalties for non-compliance, and urged the Commission to allocate sufficient funding, particularly under the Common Agricultural Policy, to support implementation. Parliament also demanded regular monitoring and reporting on the scheme’s impact, with a focus on market performance, consumer trust, and rural development outcomes, while underscoring the importance of international cooperation to protect EU products in global trade agreements.

title: Animal health: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on Animal Health
background: Heightened cross-border trade complexities, fragmented EU animal health legislation, and incidents like the 2013 horsemeat scandal underscored gaps in food chain oversight. The Parliament will discuss updating EU animal health regulations to harmonize disease prevention measures and strengthen food safety controls across member states.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the prohibition on live decoy birds for hunting, arguing they enable disease monitoring in wild birds, directly contradicting the issue's emphasis on standardized preventive measures.  
EFD absolutely doubts centralized antimicrobial regulations, advocating instead for hunter-led wildlife surveillance systems inconsistent with the issue's harmonization goals.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of local ecological knowledge promoted by EFD, prioritizing bureaucratic pharmacovigilance over grassroots hunter networks.  
EFD's insistence on cost-free wildlife monitoring through hunters conflicts with the issue's structured cross-border cooperation frameworks and budgeted health protections.  
The issue's 20% antimicrobial reduction target is incompatible with EFD's defense of unrestricted veterinary practices in wildlife management contexts.

GREEN_EFA entirely agrees the issue’s insistence on independent governmental controls for veterinary medicinal products, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preventing corporate interference in public health oversight.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the harmonization of pharmacovigilance systems and cross-border cooperation, recognizing these as vital to combating antimicrobial resistance across the EU.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity of retaining stringent accountability measures, such as explicitly naming violators in national reports, to ensure transparency and deter non-compliance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the binding 20% antimicrobial reduction target by 2030, reflecting their unwavering prioritization of One Health principles and sustainable farming practices.  
GREEN_EFA supports proportionate implementation measures, such as flexible electronic tagging derogations for sheep, provided they uphold traceability goals and reduce burdens on farmers without compromising animal health standards.

ECR slightly advocates harmonization goals but requests amending Article 12 to replace "shall levy fees" with "may levy fees" to preserve member state fiscal autonomy  
ECR objects to including cloning and animal transport duration limits in the regulation, citing irrelevance to core animal health objectives in Section 5(b)  
ECR requests revisions ensuring flexible cross-border animal movement protocols between Northern Ireland and Ireland under Chapter 9 to protect existing trade frameworks  
ECR supports mandatory dog registration amendments but urges separate diplomatic pressure to counter politically motivated trade barriers like Russia's pork embargo  
ECR rejects plant health provisions in Title III as disproportionate, advocating risk-based phytosanitary controls instead of blanket import restrictions

GUE_NGL strongly approves the harmonization of EU animal movement rules, aligning with their commitment to recognizing Ireland as a single epidemiological unit to eliminate trade barriers and anticompetitive practices.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly reference all-Ireland animal health strategies, ensuring partition does not obstruct cross-border trade or veterinary cooperation.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s emphasis on robust official controls, which advances their priority of preventing food safety crises like the horsemeat scandal through stringent oversight.  
GUE_NGL endorses the issue’s cross-border pharmacovigilance measures, urging their extension to Ireland to unify disease management and uphold public health safeguards.  
GUE_NGL recommends enhancing transparency in meat trade audits to align with the issue’s anti-fraud goals and deter market exploitation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0260) on veterinary medicinal products, emphasizing the need to address antimicrobial resistance, harmonize EU market rules, and ensure public and animal health protections. The resolution supported stricter regulations on antimicrobial use, including banning prophylactic and metaphylactic non-therapeutic applications, promoting responsible use to reduce antimicrobial resistance risks, and enhancing transparency in veterinary drug distribution. It stressed harmonizing authorization procedures for veterinary medicines across member states, improving pharmacovigilance systems, and ensuring cross-border cooperation. The Parliament also advocated for measures to reduce veterinary antimicrobial use by 20% by 2030, stricter oversight of antimicrobial sales, and incentives for developing novel antimicrobials. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and directed its position to be forwarded to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to align legislative efforts.

title: Adjustment rate to direct payments provided for in Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 in respect of calendar year 2013: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on fixing an adjustment rate to direct payments provided for in Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 in respect of calendar year 2013
background: The European Commission proposed adjusting 2013 direct payment rates under Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 to align with 2014 budget constraints amid ongoing negotiations for the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss the proposed adjustment mechanism for agricultural subsidies to maintain expenditure within agreed financial ceilings.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts maintaining exemptions for small agricultural holdings under €5,000 to protect vulnerable farmers, aligning with social cohesion priorities.  
EPP approves the issue’s budgetary discipline mechanism while proposing enhanced fairness through linear adjustments across member states to prevent disproportionate national burdens.  
EPP emphasizes alignment with Article 349 TFEU by advocating explicit exemptions for ultra-peripheral regions’ direct payments to address structural disadvantages.  
EPP endorses threshold-based reductions as a progressive measure but urges clearer harmonization of exemption criteria to prevent fragmentation.  
EPP highlights the necessity of synchronizing this adjustment with ongoing CAP reform trilogues to ensure policy coherence across funding periods.

ALDE supports the adjustment rate proposal but advises maintaining equal treatment through linear cuts across all member states to uphold financial discipline and fairness, as emphasized in the issue’s focus on policy coherence.  
ALDE suggests limiting direct payment reductions to the Commission’s initial 0.7% threshold for farmers above €5,000, opposing the higher 5% cut to prevent disproportionate budgetary impacts on agricultural stakeholders.  
ALDE recommends funding the market crisis reserve through alternative budget lines rather than excessive CAP reductions, ensuring alignment with the issue’s goal of balanced fiscal responsibility.  
ALDE advises against exempting small farms from cuts, stressing the need for gradual adaptation across all farm sizes to avoid distorting long-term agricultural sustainability.  
ALDE underscores the importance of interinstitutional dialogue to harmonize austerity measures with equitable burden-sharing, reflecting the issue’s emphasis on procedural integrity.

ECR rejects the proposed EUR 5 000 threshold as firmly opposeing with their principle of equal burden-sharing across all agricultural producers.  
ECR opposes selective financial discipline measures that disproportionately penalize medium and large farms, creating Orwellian "more equal" treatment tiers.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of budgetary fairness by exempting 80% of beneficiaries while concentrating austerity on 20% of farmers.  
ECR condemns the adjustment rate mechanism as incompatible with creating a unified agricultural market, directly contradicting their advocacy for pan-European parity.  
This proposal's structural bias against Member States with consolidated farm structures violates ECR's core commitment to non-discriminatory policy frameworks.

GUE_NGL strongly advocates the issue's budgetary discipline objectives while proposing to enhance regional equity through Amendment 12 exclusion clauses.  
GUE_NGL applauds the focus on legislative coherence but urges amending Article 2 to exempt ultra-peripheral regions and Aegean islands from crisis reserve contributions.  
This aligns perfectly with GUE_NGL's commitment to protecting vulnerable territories' special status under POSEI frameworks.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that maintaining 2013 funding levels for outermost regions would strengthen rather than contradict the issue's agricultural solidarity goals.  
The proposal effectively advances budgetary responsibility if modified to honor prior commitments about these regions' distinct needs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0159) concerning agricultural policy, adopting a first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures under Article 43(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts to ensure alignment with legislative intent. The resolution drew on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s report (A7-0186/2013) and incorporated the Committee on Budgets’ opinion, reflecting a focus on policy coherence and budgetary implications. By finalizing its position, Parliament aimed to shape the legislative outcome while safeguarding procedural integrity and interinstitutional collaboration.

title: Contractual relations in the milk and milk products sector: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1234/2007 as regards contractual relations in the milk and milk products sector
background: Following the 2009 EU milk market crisis and 2008 decision to abolish milk quotas by 2015, structural challenges included supply chain imbalances, price volatility, and weakened producer bargaining power. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to address contractual relations between farmers and processors, enhance producer organizations, and improve sector transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP completely sanctions the issue's provisions enabling milk producers to organize into stronger units through competition law derogations, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to empowering agricultural competitiveness.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the geographic protection mechanisms for vulnerable regions, urging future Commission proposals to operationalize grass-based production sustainability as a natural extension of this framework.  
EPP completely sanctions contractual standardization between farmers and processors while proposing enhanced supply chain transparency measures between retailers and dairies as a logical next policy phase.  
EPP perfectly supports the issue's compliance with Articles 42/43 TFEU, emphasizing its congruence with EPP's agricultural policy coherence objectives across single market rules.  
EPP completely sanctions the trialogue compromise on interprofessional organizations, viewing it as foundational for post-2015 quota reforms requiring subsequent market stabilization instruments.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the allowance of dairy collectives up to 3.5% market share, which entrenches dominance of existing large dairies controlling over 6% of production, contradicting fair market access principles.  
GREEN_EFA rejects voluntary contractual frameworks as ineffective, citing the issue’s failure to mandate price transparency or binding agreements, leaving producers vulnerable to exploitative industry practices.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the omission of production monitoring mechanisms post-milk quotas, warning this omission replicates pre-crisis conditions and prioritizes industrial interests over smallholder sustainability.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the issue’s alignment with Article 42 TFEU, arguing it neglects mandatory interprofessional associations to balance stakeholder power, as exemplified by regional collapses in Galicia and Denmark.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s inconsistency with environmental and social equity goals, noting concentrated industrial farms exacerbate ecological damage without crisis-proofing via public oversight.

ECR strongly endorses the proposal’s emphasis on regulating contractual relations to strengthen dairy farmers’ bargaining power, aligning with their commitment to equitable agricultural markets and crisis resilience.  
ECR approves the flexibility granted to Member States in tailoring contract regulations, proposing that such autonomy be paired with EU-level safeguards to prevent market distortions while addressing regional disparities.  
ECR endorses the abolition of milk quotas as a progressive shift toward market-driven competitiveness, reflecting their principles of reducing bureaucratic overreach and fostering economic efficiency.  
ECR highlights the necessity of bolstering farmer cooperatives and associations, urging explicit integration of cooperative support mechanisms in the regulation’s implementation to protect small-scale producers.  
ECR commends the issue’s adherence to Articles 42 and 43 TFEU, reinforcing their advocacy for harmonizing EU agricultural coherence with respect for national subsidiarity.

GUE_NGL totally doubts the issue's alignment with milk quota abolition, which perpetuates market deregulation favoring corporate interests over small producers' survival.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to mandate price controls, directly conflicting with their demand for cost-based producer compensation and equitable value distribution.  
The issue's promotion of export-driven intensification contradicts GUE_NGL's environmental priorities and food sovereignty principles, enabling ecologically harmful production models.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's reliance on voluntary contracts as structurally biased toward processors and retailers, ignoring power imbalances critical to their advocacy for binding safeguards.  
By accelerating dairy sector concentration in wealthier Member States, the issue undermines GUE_NGL's anti-dumping stance and defense of regional agricultural diversity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning agricultural and rural development (COM(2010)0728), adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s report (A7-0262/2011). It emphasized compliance with EU principles, particularly addressing concerns from the Polish Diet regarding subsidiarity, which argued the proposal overstepped national competencies. The resolution urged the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, ensuring legislative oversight. It also instructed the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting procedural adherence while integrating feedback from the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2011 opinion. The resolution focused on aligning the proposal with Treaty objectives under Articles 42 and 43(2) TFEU, balancing EU-wide agricultural policy coherence with respect for member state autonomy.

title: Financing of the common agricultural policy: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1290/2005 on the financing of the common agricultural policy and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 165/94 and Council Regulation (EC) No 78/2008
background: The Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force introduced revised EU legislative procedures, replacing comitology with delegated and implementing acts. This necessitated alignment of existing CAP financing regulations under Articles 290 and 291 TFEU, amid national parliamentary scrutiny on subsidiarity. The Parliament will discuss updating CAP financial mechanisms to comply with post-Lisbon institutional frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely sanctions the issue’s alignment with Lisbon Treaty codecision powers, perfectly reflecting their commitment to legislative clarity and delegated act flexibility in CAP governance.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s rejection of Council inflexibility on implementing acts, emphasizing Parliament’s role as colegislator to ensure democratic agricultural policymaking.  
EPP fully supports integrating critical CAP provisions into basic acts, advancing their priority of direct parliamentary oversight over technical and financial implementation details.  
EPP endorses the issue’s urgency in concluding Treaty alignment before CAP reform negotiations, viewing this as essential to uphold institutional parity with the Council.  
EPP perfectly aligns with maintaining crisis reserve mechanisms and modulated payments, reinforcing their manifesto focus on market stability and equitable competition across Member States.

EFD supports the simplification measures in rural development programs, particularly the reduction of administrative reporting requirements, aligning with efforts to reduce bureaucratic burdens.  
EFD advises maintaining support for producer associations in the fruit and vegetable sector, as highlighted in the issue, to strengthen collective bargaining power.  
EFD proposes amending provisions on Commission implementing acts to ensure parliamentary oversight, addressing concerns over democratic accountability raised during debate.  
EFD suggests reviewing subsidy allocations for organic farming to prioritize cost-efficiency and equitable access across agricultural sectors.  
EFD supports allowing regional program flexibility in financial decommitment calculations, as this respects Member States' operational autonomy.

ALDE fully accepts the issue's insistence on upholding colegislative powers under the Lisbon Treaty, perfectly aligning with their commitment to institutional parity in EU decision-making.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on transmitting positions to all EU institutions, reinforcing their longstanding priority of inter-institutional accountability.  
ALDE fully accepts the incorporation of national parliaments' subsidiarity concerns, recognizing this as vital to maintaining balanced EU legislative frameworks.  
ALDE strongly promotes the issue's demand for Commission re-engagement on amendments, seeing this as essential for preserving parliamentary oversight rights.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's legal rigor in citing TFEU Articles 42 and 43(2), reflecting their constitutionalist approach to agricultural policy governance.

SD absolutely endorses the issue's strict adherence to Treaty of Lisbon provisions, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to reinforcing parliamentary sovereignty in CAP governance.  
SD perfectly aligns with the insistence on maintaining delegated acts as originally proposed by the Commission, ensuring legal certainty and uninterrupted farmer support through Treaty-compliant mechanisms.  
SD absolutely endorses Parliament's institutional role in CAP implementation decisions, effectively advancing SD's priority of democratic accountability in EU agricultural spending.  
SD perfectly supports rejecting Council attempts to dilute parliamentary oversight through implementing acts, upholding Lisbon Treaty principles of institutional balance.  
SD absolutely endorses transmitting the issue to national parliaments, strengthening subsidiarity dialogues while preserving unified CAP management under TFEU frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2010)0745) concerning agricultural policy under Articles 42 and 43(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), adopting its first-reading stance while addressing concerns over subsidiarity. It noted the Polish Senate’s reasoned objection under Protocol No 2, which argued the proposal violated subsidiarity principles, alongside contributions from the Italian, Portuguese, and Romanian parliaments. The resolution incorporated the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of 4 May 2011 and urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing adherence to TFEU legal frameworks and procedural accountability.

title: Common organisation of agricultural markets and specific provisions for certain agricultural products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a common organisation of agricultural markets and on specific provisions for certain agricultural products (Single CMO Regulation)
background: The Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force required updating EU agricultural legislation to align with revised institutional procedures, particularly replacing comitology with delegated and implementing acts. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to the Single Common Market Organisation Regulation under the Treaty’s legal framework for agricultural policy implementation.

stances.stance:
EPP totally agrees the issue's insistence on Treaty-compliant delegation of agricultural policy authority, perfectly aligning with their commitment to parliamentary sovereignty in CAP legislation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of subsidiarity principles in CAP reforms, endorsing the integration of national parliamentary objections to preserve Member State policymaking autonomy.  
EPP unreservedly supports maintaining crisis reserve funding levels and modulation mechanisms as critical tools for stabilizing EU agricultural markets, reflecting their manifesto pledge for food security.  
EPP strongly advocates for transparent trialogue processes with expanded committee access, reinforcing the issue's demand for democratic accountability in technical agricultural negotiations.  
EPP completely agrees with anchoring substance lists in regulatory annexes to prevent discretionary Council overreach, upholding Parliament's colegislative rights under TFEU Article 290.

EFD supports the simplification measures in rural development, particularly the reduction of administrative burdens through streamlined reporting requirements.  
EFD advises reviewing the allocation of subsidies for organic farming to ensure cost-effectiveness and equitable access across agricultural sectors.  
EFD expresses concern over perceived Commission overreach in implementing acts, urging stricter adherence to subsidiarity principles.  
EFD endorses maintaining support for producer associations in the fruit and vegetable sector as vital for market stability.  
EFD suggests prioritizing policy adjustments that address immediate market pressures on conventional farmers, such as grain price volatility.

ALDE firmly sanctions the issue’s insistence on strict adherence to subsidiarity and proportionality, perfectly aligning with the party’s foundational principle of safeguarding national policymaking autonomy while ensuring EU competence remains narrowly tailored.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for robust interinstitutional dialogue, reflecting the party’s unwavering commitment to defending Parliament’s colegislative authority under the Lisbon Treaty against Council overreach on implementing acts.  
ALDE fully supports the prioritization of Treaty compliance under TFEU Articles 42 and 43(2), viewing this as critical to advancing agricultural reforms that respect shared decision-making and prevent unilateral Council dominance.  
ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s integration of national parliaments’ subsidiarity objections, recognizing this as a necessary procedural safeguard to uphold the EU’s constitutional balance in agricultural market governance.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s call for Commission accountability, which directly advances the party’s mandate to ensure Parliament’s equal role in shaping agricultural secondary legislation post-Lisbon, as emphasized in the debate’s critique of institutional power imbalances.

SD completely supports the issue’s strict adherence to Treaty of Lisbon protocols, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to reinforcing Parliament’s legislative authority in agricultural policymaking.  
SD perfectly aligns with the insistence on delegated acts as essential tools to safeguard democratic accountability, countering the Council’s attempts to dilute parliamentary oversight through implementing acts.  
SD completely supports the prioritization of subsidiarity compliance, ensuring agricultural market measures remain legally sound and insulated from judicial challenges that could destabilize farmer support systems.  
SD applauds the issue’s defense of interinstitutional balance, effectively advancing S&D’s mandate to protect integrated EU policies from fragmented national interventions.  
SD emphasizes the critical linkage between Treaty fidelity and policy continuity, ensuring CAP reforms remain focused on substantive farmer protections rather than procedural disputes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s legislative proposal on agricultural policy reform (COM(2010)0799), emphasizing compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It noted reasoned objections from the national parliaments of Luxembourg, Poland, and Sweden, which argued the proposal overstepped EU competence into national policymaking. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, outlined in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s report (A7-0322/2011), and urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or alternative texts were proposed. It further instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting its commitment to interinstitutional dialogue and adherence to procedural safeguards under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 42, 43(2), and 294). The resolution integrated the European Economic and Social Committee’s March 2011 opinion but prioritized addressing subsidiarity concerns while advancing agricultural policy objectives.

title: Common rules for direct support schemes for farmers: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 establishing common rules for direct support schemes for farmers under the common agricultural policy and establishing certain support schemes for farmers
background: The Treaty of Lisbon (2009) introduced new legislative procedures requiring alignment of existing EU regulations with delegated and implementing acts. The European Commission proposed amendments to Common Agricultural Policy rules on direct farmer support to comply with updated comitology frameworks. The Parliament will discuss regulatory adjustments to align agricultural policy with post-Lisbon Treaty governance structures.

stances.stance:
EPP fully supports the issue’s alignment with Parliament’s codecision authority under the Lisbon Treaty, ensuring agricultural legislation prioritizes democratic oversight and legal clarity for farmers.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the necessity of embedding core agricultural policies within primary legislation to uphold parliamentary authority over CAP reforms, as emphasized in Articles 42 and 43(2) TFEU.  
EPP fully supports advancing plenary votes to assert Parliament’s role as co-legislator, reinforcing the commitment to transparent and decisive policymaking when consensus with the Council proves unattainable.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on maintaining a firm negotiating mandate to ensure balanced inter-institutional dialogue, reflecting Parliament’s demonstrated compromise readiness contrasted with Council inflexibility.  
EPP fully supports the strategic allocation of direct payments to stabilize food markets and safeguard agricultural competitiveness, consistent with the issue’s focus on proportionate subsidiarity adherence.

EFD supports the issue’s procedural accountability measures but advises reassessing disproportionate support for organic farming schemes to prioritize cost-effective relief for all farmers amid rising input costs.  
EFD highlights concerns over bureaucratic overreach in Commission implementing acts, urging stricter adherence to subsidiarity to prevent democratic deficits under Lisbon Treaty frameworks.  
EFD endorses simplifying rural development reporting requirements and maintaining producer association support in the fruit and vegetable sector as steps toward reducing administrative burdens.  
EFD suggests amending regional financial decommitment rules to allow Member State-level calculations, ensuring flexibility for diverse agricultural systems.  
EFD advises reallocating resources from niche environmental schemes to address urgent market pressures, such as grain price volatility, while retaining core rural development objectives.

ALDE firmly endorses the issue’s insistence on strict subsidiarity compliance, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle of balanced EU governance that respects national competencies.  
ALDE recognizes the issue as a robust defense of Parliament’s colegislative rights under the Lisbon Treaty, directly countering the Council’s attempts to marginalize parliamentary oversight in agricultural policy.  
The issue’s demand for Commission accountability in reassessing proposal scope resonates perfectly with ALDE’s advocacy for institutional parity and Treaty fidelity.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s procedural reinforcement of inter-institutional dialogue, advancing their long-standing priority of transparent, collaborative EU decision-making.  
This position exemplifies ALDE’s unwavering commitment to ensuring Lisbon-era power-sharing prevails over outdated Council-centric approaches in CAP governance.

SD completely advocates the strict adherence to delegated acts under the Lisbon Treaty, perfectly aligning with Parliament’s enhanced role in safeguarding democratic agricultural policy processes.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s insistence on legal compliance to prevent CAP suspension, ensuring uninterrupted support for farmers through Treaty-conforming mechanisms.  
SD fully supports the Commission’s original proposal as legally robust, emphasizing its necessity to avoid Court of Justice challenges that would destabilize CAP implementation.  
SD strongly advocates for inter-institutional balance, endorsing the issue’s reinforcement of Parliament’s authority against Council attempts to dilute delegated act provisions.  
SD emphasizes unwavering alignment with Lisbon Treaty principles, ensuring substantive policy debates over technicalities to advance farmers’ interests through CAP reforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the compliance of the Commission’s 2010 legislative proposal (COM(2010)0539) with the principle of subsidiarity, following reasoned objections from the Lithuanian, Luxembourg, and Polish parliaments. The resolution, grounded in Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Articles 42 and 43(2) on agriculture, emphasized the need to align the proposal with EU competences while acknowledging the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2011 opinion. It adopted Parliament’s first-reading position, urging the Commission to reassess the proposal’s scope to ensure adherence to subsidiarity and proportionality. The resolution further called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or alternative texts were proposed and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural accountability and inter-institutional dialogue.

title: Decision on the opening of, and mandate for, interinstitutional negotiations on common organisation of the markets in agricultural products (Single CMO Regulation): PROPOSAL FOR A DECISION ON THE OPENING OF, AND MANDATE FOR, INTERINSTITUTIONAL NEGOTIATIONS  on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a common organisation of the markets in agricultural products (Single CMO Regulation)
background: The European Commission proposed reforms to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) as part of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations, aiming to modernize EU agricultural market regulations. The Parliament will discuss initiating interinstitutional negotiations on establishing a common organization of agricultural markets under the Single CMO Regulation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the integration of greening measures into direct payments as a transformative step towards sustainable agriculture, aligning with EPP's commitment to environmental stewardship while maintaining farm competitiveness.  
EPP approves the phased elimination of historical payment systems but proposes enhanced equivalence mechanisms to recognize advanced agri-environment programs, preventing double-counting while rewarding existing sustainability efforts.  
EPP endorses the issue's budgetary linkage to MFF while suggesting accelerated convergence timelines for newer member states to address regional disparities in direct payments.  
EPP fully backs the amendment ensuring Baltic states receive at least 55% of EU average payments by 2014, viewing this as critical for achieving fair competition within single market principles.  
EPP strongly agrees maintaining vineyard planting rights until 2018 and milk quotas until 2020, effectively advancing market stability for Mediterranean and small-scale producers.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to mandate binding ecological farming practices, fully disapproveing with their demand for 7% chemical-free ecological focus areas and crop rotation requirements.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the allowance of export subsidies in the proposal, which directly contradicts their principle of ending trade-distorting practices harming developing nations.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of meaningful subsidy redistribution, highlighting that the 300,000€ payment cap proposal ignores their call for a 100,000€ limit to prioritize small-scale farmers.  
GREEN_EFA fully disapproves with the issue's omission of a protein strategy to reduce unsustainable soy imports, a critical gap in addressing industrial livestock overproduction.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the procedural undermining of ambitious greening amendments, particularly the failure to prioritize crop rotation votes over weaker diversification measures as required by parliamentary rules.

ECR completely disapproves the reintroduction of market intervention mechanisms as outlined in the Single CMO Regulation, which they condemn as a regressive return to production quotas and price guarantees inconsistent with competitive agriculture.  
ECR rejects the proposed greening requirements as bureaucratic overreach that imposes unworkable land management constraints while failing to deliver meaningful environmental benefits.  
The issue’s failure to fully eliminate payment disparities between old and new Member States directly contradicts ECR’s demand for immediate budgetary equality across all EU farmers.  
ECR condemns the sugar regime extension as market-distorting protectionism that advantages beet producers over cane refiners, undermining fair competition.  
The proposal’s tolerance for coupled payments and risk management subsidies in Pillar Two is denounced as financially irresponsible, rewarding inefficiency contrary to ECR’s free-market principles.

GUE_NGL rejects the negotiation mandate as absolutely doubting with their demand for equitable agricultural subsidies, citing the issue's failure to cap payments below €100 000 and redistribute funds to small-scale sustainable farming.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal's market-driven framework for overlooking critical aspects like price regulation mechanisms and binding quotas to stabilize dairy and sugar production, which they deem essential to counter corporate agribusiness dominance.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s silence on environmental safeguards, particularly its allowance of weakened greening requirements that perpetuate industrialized farming’s pollution of EU water systems.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s inconsistency with food sovereignty principles by permitting free-trade policies that undermine local production and fail to establish social/environmental border tariffs.  
GUE_NGL demands rejection of the mandate until it incorporates mandatory support for public agricultural insurance and strict definitions of "active farmers" to exclude absentee landowners and speculative entities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to address the financial framework for agricultural and rural development policies, emphasizing that the proposed financial envelope for these initiatives remains indicative and contingent upon the final agreement on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) regulation for 2014-2020. It highlighted the interdependence between the legislative proposal’s budgetary allocation and the broader MFF negotiations, stressing that definitive funding levels cannot be established until the overarching financial framework is adopted. To advance this process, the Parliament decided to initiate interinstitutional negotiations based on the mandate that the financial provisions must align with the eventual MFF agreement, ensuring coherence and feasibility in funding agricultural and rural development programs during the specified seven-year period.

title: Decision on the opening of, and mandate for, interinstitutional negotiations on direct payments to farmers under support schemes within the framework of the CAP: PROPOSAL FOR A DECISION ON THE OPENING OF, AND MANDATE FOR, INTERINSTITUTIONAL NEGOTIATIONS on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing rules for direct payments to farmers under support schemes within the framework of the common agricultural policy
background: The European Parliament's co-legislative role under the Lisbon Treaty required engagement in reforming Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) direct payments for 2014-2020, aligning with EU budgetary frameworks and addressing agricultural sustainability, market stability, and equitable fund distribution. The Parliament will discuss initiating interinstitutional negotiations on CAP support schemes' financial rules and implementation mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the integration of greening requirements into direct payments, ensuring environmental accountability while maintaining agricultural productivity. This aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to sustainable farming practices.  
EPP endorses the issue's emphasis on budgetary coherence with the multiannual financial framework, ensuring CAP reforms maintain strategic priorities for rural development. The issue effectively advances EPP's priority of linking agricultural support to long-term EU objectives.  
EPP advocates for accelerated payment convergence mechanisms to address historical disparities, particularly supporting Amendment 139 to ensure Baltic states reach at least 75% of the EU average payment by 2019 as a fairness imperative.  
EPP approves the recognition of equivalent environmental benefits between agri-environment programs and greening measures, proposing simplified administrative procedures to avoid double compliance burdens on farmers.  
EPP proposes enhanced Council transparency in sharing biophysical criteria simulations for disadvantaged area classifications during negotiations to ensure evidence-based territorial adjustments.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's approach to direct payments as fundamentally incompatible with ecological transition principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the failure to mandate 7% chemical-free ecological focus areas, contradicting their soil protection agenda.  
GREEN_EFA condemns allowing 300k€ payment ceilings instead of their demanded 100k€ cap, perpetuating industrial farm subsidies.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the absence of binding crop rotation rules, enabling destructive monocultures opposed in all party amendments.  
GREEN_EFA declares the issue illegitimate for ignoring 3.5 million lost EU farms - a crisis requiring radical redistribution unaddressed in MFF alignment debates.

ALDE supports the issue’s alignment with MFF budgetary coherence while proposing amendments to reintroduce key cross-compliance standards (SMRs/GAECs) with exemptions for carbon-rich soil management and electronic identification systems.  
ALDE advises maintaining Member State flexibility in greening implementation through Commission-monitored equivalence mechanisms to prevent environmental dilution of sustainability goals.  
ALDE cautions against expanding market intervention tools that risk distorting agricultural competitiveness, stressing the need to prioritize market-oriented approaches over surplus-dependent systems.  
ALDE strongly endorses transparency measures requiring full public disclosure of subsidy recipients to align CAP expenditures with democratic accountability principles.  
ALDE recommends conditioning Pillar 1 to Pillar 2 budget transfers on national co-financing commitments to ensure rural development programs remain adequately resourced.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal as fundamentally incompatible with their demand for price guarantees and market regulation to combat agricultural speculation  
GUE_NGL opposes the inadequate payment caps that perpetuate unequal distribution favoring agribusiness over family farms  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to implement mandatory smallholder protections and environmental visa systems at EU borders  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's contradiction with food sovereignty principles through its maintenance of destructive free-trade frameworks  
GUE_NGL demands binding quotas for sustainable production rather than market-driven reforms exacerbating rural inequality

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the provisional nature of the financial envelope outlined in the legislative proposal, emphasizing that it serves only as an indicative figure pending the finalization of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) regulation for 2014-2020. The resolution highlighted that the proposed budget cannot be definitively established until an agreement is reached on the MFF, which determines the EU’s long-term spending priorities and resource allocation. By stressing the interdependence between the legislative proposal and the broader financial framework, the Parliament underscored the need for coherence in budgetary planning to ensure alignment with strategic objectives for agriculture and rural development during the specified seven-year period.

title: Decision on the opening of, and mandate for, interinstitutional negotiations on financing, management and monitoring of the CAP: PROPOSAL FOR A DECISION ON THE OPENING OF, AND MANDATE FOR, INTERINSTITUTIONAL NEGOTIATIONS on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the financing, management and monitoring of the CAP
background: The European Union's Common Agricultural Policy undergoes periodic reforms to align with evolving agricultural, economic, and environmental priorities. Proposed regulatory updates addressing budget allocation, subsidy distribution, and compliance mechanisms under the 2014-2020 financial framework prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss interinstitutional negotiations on CAP financing, management structures, and monitoring systems.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the integration of greening requirements into Pillar 1 direct payments, aligning with their commitment to environmental sustainability while maintaining agricultural competitiveness through phased ecological focus area implementation.  
EPP endorses the gradual transition from historical payment models to regionalized systems, emphasizing the need for measured convergence to ensure fairness across member states and prevent distortions in land markets.  
EPP approves enhanced flexibility between CAP pillars, enabling member states to tailor rural development programs to local needs while maintaining strong environmental safeguards for biodiversity and climate-smart practices.  
EPP advocates maintaining strategic production capacities through coupled support measures, particularly for olive oil and wine sectors, ensuring Europe’s agricultural diversity and quality standards are preserved.  
EPP proposes accelerating payment convergence timelines for newer member states to achieve 75% of EU average by 2024 rather than 2029, addressing regional disparities while preserving budget stability.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's diluted environmental commitments as entirely conflicting with their demand for binding crop rotation and 7% chemical-free ecological focus areas.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the subsidy structure for perpetuating industrial agriculture, noting the issue's failure to cap payments at €100,000 per farm as explicitly demanded in debates.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the omission of a protein strategy to reduce soy imports, which directly contradicts their emphasis on ending ecologically destructive feed dependencies.  
GREEN_EFA opposes allowing continued exports of subsidized surpluses, a practice denounced as "suicidal" for farmers and developing nations in parliamentary interventions.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to redirect 30% of CAP funds to meaningful eco-schemes, noting its voluntary measures violate their "public money for public goods" principle.

ECR strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on fair income convergence and eliminating payment disparities for new member states, aligning with ECR’s commitment to treaty-based equality and solidarity.  
ECR approves the €50 billion allocation for climate-smart agriculture but proposes redirecting rigid environmental set-aside requirements to innovation-driven precision farming to enhance competitiveness.  
ECR endorses simplified administrative frameworks for small farmers, advocating automatic inclusion of those receiving under €2,000 in support to reduce bureaucratic overhead.  
ECR commends rural development funding for digitalization but urges greater flexibility in greening measures through targeted Pillar Two schemes tailored to local needs.  
ECR highlights the need to revise sugar market provisions to ensure equal access for cane refiners and beet processors, fostering competition while maintaining food security goals.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposed CAP financing framework for maintaining excessive payment caps that disproportionately benefit large agri-businesses, contradicting their demand for redistributive aid targeting small farms.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue's market-oriented approach as firmly doubting with their principles of food sovereignty, citing the absence of price guarantees and production quotas to stabilize farmer incomes.  
GUE/NGL condemns the insufficient environmental safeguards, arguing that the 50% pesticide reduction target overlooks the need to dismantle industrialized farming models polluting EU water systems.  
GUE/NGL rejects the failure to abolish sugar production quotas by 2015, a measure critical to reducing consumer prices and supporting Latvian agricultural competitiveness as raised by Alfreds Rubiks.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue's silence on public agricultural insurance and mandatory smallholder systems, which they deem essential to protect economically vulnerable farming households.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the challenges facing agricultural sectors and rural communities, emphasizing the need for sustainable practices, fair income for farmers, and enhanced biodiversity protection. It advocated for increased funding under the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) to support small and medium-sized farms, with specific allocations of €50 billion over the next five years for climate-smart initiatives and €10 billion for rural development programs targeting digitalization and youth employment. The resolution called for stricter enforcement of environmental regulations, including reducing pesticide use by 50% by 2030 and allocating 30% of CAP funds to eco-schemes. It also urged member states to prioritize animal welfare standards and ensure transparent food supply chains to address market imbalances. Additionally, the Parliament stressed the importance of aligning agricultural policies with the European Green Deal and achieving carbon neutrality in the sector by 2040.

title: Decision on the opening of, and mandate for, interinstitutional negotiations on support for rural development by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD): PROPOSAL FOR A DECISION ON THE OPENING OF, AND MANDATE FOR, INTERINSTITUTIONAL NEGOTIATIONS on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on support for rural development by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD)
background: The European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) operates within the Common Agricultural Policy framework, with its financial allocation contingent on the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations. The Parliament will discuss initiating interinstitutional negotiations on the legislative proposal for EAFRD-supported rural development programs under the post-2013 CAP reforms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the integration of greening requirements into direct payments under Pillar One, ensuring environmental accountability while maintaining agricultural productivity. This aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to harmonizing sustainability with competitive farming practices.  
EPP approves the issue’s emphasis on administrative simplification by advocating equivalence between agri-environment programs and greening measures, thereby avoiding penalization of proactive farmers already exceeding baseline environmental standards.  
EPP strongly endorses the gradual alignment of direct payments across member states, proposing an amendment to ensure Baltic states reach 75% of the EU average payment by 2019 as a targeted enhancement opportunity for equitable rural development.  
EPP applauds the flexibility to transfer funds between Pillar One and Pillar Two, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of empowering regions to tailor rural development strategies to local agricultural needs.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of maintaining planting rights for vineyards and dairy quotas until market-stabilizing alternatives are operational, safeguarding specialized sectors critical to rural economies.

GREEN_EFA slightly agrees the financial framework alignment but demands binding greening measures, including mandatory crop rotation and 7% ecological focus areas without chemical use, as the issue's provisional envelope fails to enforce environmental safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA requests revisions to cap direct payments at €100,000 per farm to ensure fair distribution, opposing the current proposal's €300,000 threshold that benefits large agribusinesses over small-scale farmers.  
GREEN_EFA completely againsts with the issue's silence on eliminating export subsidies, which perpetuates market distortions harmful to developing countries' agricultural sectors.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the inclusion of commodity speculation mechanisms like crop insurance in rural development funding, advocating instead for redirected resources to short supply chains and organic farming transitions.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's failure to mandate impact assessments on global food systems, inconsistent with their principle of policy coherence for development.

SD strongly sanctions the mandatory 30% allocation for greening measures in Pillar 1, aligning with SD's commitment to environmental sustainability in agricultural policy.  
SD applauds the historic approval of payment capping at 300,000€ while proposing to strengthen redistributive effects through enhanced degressivity for holdings above 100,000€.  
SD endorses the 25% rural development budget reservation for organic farming and agro-environmental measures, effectively advancing climate resilience priorities.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for mandatory public transparency of CAP beneficiaries through annual disclosures, proposing an amendment to Article 12 on accountability mechanisms.  
SD fully backs youth incentives and local supply chain support provisions as essential tools for generational renewal in rural areas, matching SD's 2024 Rural Revitalization Agenda.

GUE_NGL rejects the mandate for interinstitutional negotiations due to the proposal's failure to cap direct payments at a level ensuring equitable redistribution to small-scale and sustainable agricultural practices.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the absence of binding mechanisms to prioritize public investment in agroecological transitions, contradicting their demand for environmental and social conditionality in funding allocation.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s inconsistency with food sovereignty principles, as it neglects mandatory price guarantees and production regulation to counter market speculation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the financial framework’s perpetuation of aid concentration among large agribusinesses, which directly conflicts with their stance to limit payments to €100\xa0000 and reallocate resources to vulnerable farmers.  
GUE_NGL underscores the proposal’s disregard for quota systems and preferential national regimes, critical to protecting small producers from deregulated trade policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the provisional nature of the financial envelope outlined in the legislative proposal, emphasizing that its final amount cannot be definitively determined until an agreement is reached on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) regulation for the years 2014-2020. The resolution underscored that the proposed financial allocation serves merely as an indicative reference for the legislative authority and stressed the necessity of aligning it with the broader budgetary framework to ensure coherence and feasibility in funding agricultural and rural development policies during the specified period.

title: Direct payments to farmers: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 as regards the application of direct payments to farmers in respect of the year 2013
background: The 2013 transition between the 2007-2013 and 2014-2020 EU budget frameworks necessitated adjustments to direct payments under the Common Agricultural Policy, particularly for new Member States phasing into the system. The Parliament will discuss amending existing regulations to ensure continuity of farmer support during the policy reform interim period.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely endorses the issue's alignment with Treaty principles under Article 43(2) TFEU, perfectly reflecting its commitment to legally grounded agricultural policy frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for maintaining uninterrupted direct payment structures in 2013, recognizing this as essential transitional stability for newer Member States like Bulgaria and Romania.  
EPP proposes strengthening future CAP reforms to accelerate payment equalization, framing this as a natural extension of the issue's fairness principles rather than a modification.  
EPP entirely endorses the institutional collaboration mechanism outlined, seeing this as vital for upholding the EU's decision-making integrity across agricultural and budgetary domains.  
EPP perfectly supports the issue's rejection of net payment ceilings for newer Member States, viewing this as foundational to achieving competitive parity across all farming sectors.

ALDE absolutely upholds the issue's retention of payment continuity mechanisms, perfectly aligning with their commitment to stable agricultural policy frameworks during transitional periods.  
ALDE applauds the inclusion of voluntary modulation flexibility, effectively advancing their priority of empowering national governments to address rural development funding gaps.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on inter-institutional collaboration, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for cooperative EU decision-making processes.  
ALDE absolutely upholds the procedural clarity in implementing 2013 direct payments, ensuring compliance with Treaty obligations while safeguarding farmer interests.  
ALDE commends the issue’s responsiveness to national parliamentary concerns, demonstrating alignment with their principle of subsidiarity in agricultural fund management.

SD fully approves the transitional provisions enabling new Member States to maintain complementary national support in 2013, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to equitable agricultural development across EU regions.  
SD perfectly aligns with the rapporteur's compromise ensuring uninterrupted direct payment continuity through 2013, safeguarding farmer stability during CAP reform negotiations as mandated by SD priorities.  
SD fully approves the harmonization of direct payment frameworks to prevent disadvantages for new Member States transitioning from SAPS to SPS systems, reflecting SD's core principle of fair treatment in agricultural policy.  
SD perfectly supports the issue's foundational role in advancing single-market parity for farmers, aligning with SD's unyielding stance against unjustified payment disparities between Member States.  
SD fully approves the accelerated legislative timeline for 2013 implementation, exemplifying SD's institutional collaboration priorities while maintaining agricultural subsidy predictability.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s transitional approach to direct payments but proposes amending Article 3 to specify minimum payments at 80% of the EU average, addressing systemic inequities for Baltic farmers.  
GUE_NGL advises replacing surface area-based aid calculations with labor-centric models in Annex II to prioritize small farms and ecological practices over industrial agriculture.  
GUE_NGL highlights concerns about rural depopulation linked to current payment disparities, urging supplemental clauses to restrict speculative land acquisitions by non-resident entities.  
GUE_NGL calls for integrating regional price-setting mechanisms into CAP reforms to stabilize agricultural incomes and reflect production cost variations across member states.  
GUE_NGL stresses the need to expand CAP budget allocations for social justice, ensuring direct payments actively combat poverty migration from rural areas.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0630) concerning agricultural and rural development policy, aligning with the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s report and the Committee on Budgets’ opinion. It emphasized adherence to Treaty provisions (Article 43(2) TFEU) for shaping common agricultural policy measures and urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements were planned. The resolution also directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting institutional collaboration while prioritizing legislative clarity and procedural accountability.

title: Motions for resolutions - Crisis in the dairy farming sector: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the crisis in the dairy farming sector
background: A sharp decline in EU dairy prices, falling below production costs, and reduced global demand amid economic downturn strained farmer viability, compounded by increased international supply and domestic market imbalances. The Parliament will discuss measures to address the dairy sector crisis, focusing on market stabilization and sustainable sectoral support.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the immediate creation of the €600 million EU Dairy Fund, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to farm modernization and intergenerational renewal in rural communities.  
EPP approves the issue's focus on price transparency mechanisms, particularly endorsing mandatory origin labeling and market abuse investigations to bridge the producer-consumer price gap.  
EPP proposes enhancing butter fat utilization in industrial food processing as a targeted demand stimulus, building upon the issue's school milk program expansion.  
EPP emphasizes maintaining production capacity through crisis-era intervention tools, strongly agreeing extended butter/SMP storage periods and export refund reactivation as market stabilizers.  
EPP endorses early retirement schemes and youth farmer support through the Dairy Fund, recognizing these measures as vital for structural adaptation without opposing quota policy adjustments.

EFD rejects the issue's extension of butter and skimmed milk powder intervention periods as absolutely conflicting with EFD's opposition to structural market interventions that recreate pre-quota conditions.  
EFD opposes the proposal's failure to address exploitative supermarket profit margins, which directly contradict free market fairness principles central to EFD's platform.  
EFD condemns the issue's implicit support for super levy systems as punitive measures against efficient producers, inconsistent with claimed EU modernization goals.  
EFD demands mandatory origin labeling requirements beyond current provisions, arguing the issue's traceability measures insufficiently meet consumer transparency demands.  
EFD rejects the market stabilization framework for overlooking critical aspects like private cheese storage aid, which would better balance benefits across Member States.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's reliance on export refunds as fundamentally incompatible with their demand to cease policies that destabilize global agricultural markets.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the failure to mandate immediate 5% milk quota reductions, a measure they deem critical to protect small producers from market oversaturation.  
The proposal fully rejects with GREEN_EFA's insistence on legally binding minimum prices to cover production costs, instead prioritizing industry-led price monitoring systems.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's silence on dismantling distribution oligopolies, a structural imbalance repeatedly denounced in parliamentary debates.  
The omission of mental health safeguards for farmers facing bankruptcy directly contradicts GREEN_EFA's emphasis on the human toll of the crisis.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the issue's establishment of an EU Dairy Fund, aligning with their demand for extraordinary sectoral support to protect rural employment and small producers.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call for price transparency investigations as critical to exposing market abuses that depress farmer incomes while consumer prices rise, directly addressing Kohlíček's cost-price disparity concerns.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Clause 4 to include binding minimum intra-EU milk purchase prices, enhancing Le Hyaric's structural solution while maintaining the issue's supply-demand balance goals.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the need to maintain milk quotas until 2015 as urged by Figueiredo, suggesting modifying deregulation timelines to prevent premature market destabilization.  
This aligns perfectly with GUE_NGL's commitment to combat agricultural liberalization, particularly through expanded export refunds and labeling rules that protect EU producers from third-country competition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the severe crisis in the EU dairy market, where milk prices fell below 21 cents per liter, threatening farmers' viability as many sold below production costs, exacerbated by declining global demand and increased supply from third countries like New Zealand and the US. It criticized the Commission for inadequate crisis prediction and response, urging immediate stabilization measures, including an EU Dairy Fund of €600 million to support producers, cooperatives, farm modernization, and youth farmers, as previously requested in the 2009 budget. The resolution called for enhancing product value through high-quality dairy production, expanding initiatives like the school milk program to stimulate demand, balancing supply and demand via intervention mechanisms, and exploring early retirement schemes for farmers. It emphasized price transparency, noting consumer prices for milk and cheese rose 14% (2006-2009) while producer prices dropped 40% in some states, and demanded investigations into market abuses. Additional measures included extending butter and skimmed milk powder intervention periods until February 2010, increasing intervention prices, expanding cheese exports with refunds to third countries like the USA, and improving labeling to ensure dairy products are accurately identified. The Parliament also urged the Commission to maintain dairy sector funding post-export refund phase-out, introduce price monitoring systems, and deliver delayed reports on food price transparency and market abuses, while condemning the Council’s failure to act at its September 2009 meeting.

title: Motions for resolutions - FAO World Summit on Food Security - Eradicating hunger from the face of the earth: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the FAO Summit and food security
background: Persistent global hunger exceeding one billion people, exacerbated by climate change impacts and food price volatility, prompted international responses including the 2009 FAO World Summit and G8 L'Aquila commitments on agricultural aid. The Parliament will discuss strategies to enhance global food security and eradicate hunger through agricultural development and international cooperation.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on smallholder farmers and agroecological practices, aligning with their advocacy for localized agricultural solutions over export-driven models.  
EFD advises amending Clause 6 to explicitly phase out biofuel subsidies linked to food price volatility, citing unresolved tensions between energy policies and hunger eradication.  
EFD expresses concern over the omission of safeguards against third-country land acquisitions in vulnerable regions, urging binding provisions to prioritize local food sovereignty.  
EFD endorses the call for CAP reforms to prioritize climate resilience but proposes stricter timelines for decoupling EU subsidies from overproduction that undermines global markets.  
EFD highlights the need for accountability mechanisms in Paragraph 12, advocating for annual audits of aid effectiveness to address systemic failures in past declarations.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s alignment of CAP reforms with global food security objectives, particularly its emphasis on climate-resilient agriculture and fair trade, reflecting ALDE’s prioritization of market-integrated sustainability.  
ALDE approves the urgent call for increased agricultural investment in developing nations, reinforcing Mr. Michel’s demand for transparent funding mechanisms to operationalize the FAO’s USD 44 billion annual target.  
ALDE endorses the issue’s focus on open markets and legal system stabilization, echoing Mr. Lyon’s argument that political and institutional frameworks are prerequisites for agricultural development.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the technology transfer provisions to explicitly include digital farming tools and precision agriculture, ensuring alignment with modern productivity-enhancing innovations.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s agroecological emphasis but urges adding metrics to track progress on reducing export dependency, addressing structural imbalances highlighted in FAO/OECD projections.

SD strongly accepts the issue's alignment of CAP reforms with global food security goals, emphasizing urgent prioritization of smallholder support and climate resilience as central to SD's commitment to eradicating structural hunger.  
SD strongly endorses increased agricultural investment and technology transfer, urging immediate EU action to redirect resources toward sustainable agroecology in line with SD's equity principles.  
SD strongly approves the issue's focus on FAO/OECD market projections, advocating enhanced multilateral coordination to combat speculative practices and land-grabbing by agro-industrial corporations.  
SD proposes explicitly integrating water management systems and protections against land tenure exploitation into the issue's agroecological frameworks to address critical structural vulnerabilities.  
SD strongly commends the demand for rapid-response facility implementation, condemning G8 leadership gaps as barriers to achieving SD's humanitarian objectives through effective aid governance.

ECR supports the issue’s emphasis on sustainable agricultural development and CAP reforms to address global food security, aligning with their focus on structural solutions to hunger.  
ECR advises strengthening governance conditionality in agricultural aid, emphasizing political stability assessments for recipient countries to prevent misuse, as demonstrated by Zimbabwe’s collapse from breadbasket to food importer.  
ECR proposes amending the CAP post-reform provisions to include a defined safety net mechanism, protecting EU farmers from market volatility while maintaining contributions to global food accessibility.  
ECR highlights the need for explicit EU budget commitments to agricultural R&D, particularly in climate-resilient technologies, to meet productivity targets without transferring costs to consumers.  
ECR underscores the importance of linking technology transfer initiatives to governance accountability frameworks in vulnerable regions, ensuring alignment with the issue’s agroecological goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over global food security and rising food prices, emphasizing the need for urgent action in developing countries and alignment of EU policies with sustainable agricultural development. It referenced previous resolutions on food price crises (2007, 2008) and African agricultural development (2007), supported the establishment of a rapid-response facility (COM(2008)0450) to address food emergencies, and endorsed the McGuinness report’s recommendations to align the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) with global food security goals. The resolution highlighted FAO/OECD projections (2008-2017) warning of structural food market imbalances and stressed the IAASTD’s call for agroecological practices, smallholder support, and reduced reliance on export-driven models. It urged post-‘Health Check’ CAP reforms to prioritize food accessibility, climate resilience, and fair trade, while adhering to the Paris Declaration’s aid effectiveness principles. The Parliament also reaffirmed commitments from the 2009 World Summit on Food Security, advocating for increased investment in agriculture, technology transfer, and policies to mitigate speculation in food markets, particularly in vulnerable regions.

title: Honeybee health and beekeeping: REPORT on honeybee health and the challenges of the beekeeping sector
background: Declining honeybee populations in the EU, attributed to pests, diseases, pesticide exposure, habitat loss, and climate pressures, threatened agricultural pollination and biodiversity. Existing EU policies addressed apiculture support, pesticide regulation, and biodiversity goals. The Parliament will discuss safeguarding honeybee health, sustainable beekeeping practices, and mitigating risks to ecosystems and food security.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's reliance on pharmaceutical industry solutions as fundamentally incompatible with their ecological transition principles, citing the report's encouragement of veterinary product innovation as perpetuating chemical dependency.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the proposed pesticide risk assessment framework for failing to mandate an immediate EU-wide ban on neonicotinoids, contrary to their precautionary principle advocacy demonstrated in Amendment 327.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's inadequate critique of industrial monoculture farming, arguing that promoting "bee-friendly habitats" without binding crop rotation mandates (Article 14) ignores systemic agricultural reform needs.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to prohibit genetically modified crops linked to pollinator decline, a direct contradiction to their 2023 policy manifesto demanding a full moratorium on GM cultivation.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally disputes the effectiveness of harmonized hive monitoring systems (Section 5.2) as a substitute for reducing pesticide loads in soils, which their research identifies as the primary driver of colony collapse.

SD strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on increased EU funding for bee health research, aligning perfectly with their commitment to biodiversity and sustainable agricultural innovation.  
SD approves the strict pesticide regulations and precautionary ban on neonicotinoids, which advance their priority of eliminating chemical threats to pollinators and ecosystems.
